H0.text: Earthworms making tunnels under the surface are the animals that best help the soil hold water, because soil packing down over time decreases its water‑holding capacity.

H1.text: Cattle making depressions with their hooves are the animals that best help soil hold water as soil packs down over time, decreasing its water‑holding capacity.

H2.text: Horses making trenches when they gallop best help the soil hold water by preventing the soil from packing down over time, which otherwise decreases its water‑holding capacity.

H3.text: Sheep pulling up plants by their roots are the animals that would best help soil hold water, counteracting the soil’s tendency to pack down over time and reduce its water‑holding capacity.

A4.text: The stability of aggregates in response to water was also found to be improved when constructed by earthworms.

A5.text: Earthworms promote the formation of nutrient-rich casts (globules of soil, stable in soil mucus) that have high soil aggregation and soil fertility and quality.
